many Silicon Valley employees regard fluctuations as way of life, calculating value of options solely on potential; feel swings matter very little as long as fundamentals are sound; options, which essentially represent agreement by company to make shares available to employee for specified price in future, can yield great profit when company's stock soars, or be worth nothing if it plunges; prosecutors want to keep Federal grand jury in operation for another year to indict him; report describes in graphic detail Lewinsky's account of many meetings with President, including 10 sexual encounters in and around Oval Office, and provides narrative of Clinton's prolonged efforts to impede independent counsel's inquiry and to persuade others to assist in conspiracy to hinder investigations by Federal grand jury and Congress; even though lobbyists have long been part of capital's political fabric, new stratum of lawyers and influence-peddlers has never before been as intimately interwoven into Government and has never been as brazen in advertising its money and political connections; most Washington law firms, which 20 years ago did little or no lobbying, currently have bustling lobbying practices, and some have hired non-lawyers to increase their political clout; new cast of Republican Congressional committee and subcommittee chairmen as well as Washington's increasing impact on highly regulated industries have left lobbyists reaching much deeper into bureauracy to wield influence; demand for knowledgable people who can track goings-on in Government and can figure out relevant pressure points has greatly increased; almost anyone with significant political connections--including spouses, family members and former aides of lawmakers--is highly marketable; boutique firms that specialize in lobbying single member or single committee of Congress have sprouted up and are flourishing, and eye-popping salaries commanded by lobbyists has become fresh evidence of culture of money that in 1990's is transforming Washington's image as power city--eclipsing traditional obsession with power; at least 128 former members of Congress currently work as lobbyists; although many found solace in profession after they were defeated for re-election, others cite desire to earn more money as reason for leaving; only three percent of lawmakers who retired in 1970's are currently lobbyists, compared with 22 percent in 1990's; case of Kenneth J Kies, Republican tax lawyer who left Congresional staff position in 1997 to accept million-dollar job lobbying for Price Waterhouse Coopers, discussed; photos (L)")('1998092', "Former Labor Sec Robert B Reich Op-Ed article notes that Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee will decide in secret what to do next about short-term interest rates; contends that Federal Reserve, International Monetary Fund and Treasury are staffed by skilled economists, but questions whether choices they make are right ones in eyes of most of people whose lives are being altered by them; maintains that in short term, Federal Reserve should lower interest rates by full percentage point before year's end; holds that there should be coordinated large-scale reduction in global interest rates; asserts that important thing is that any such decisions involve subtle weighings of human needs and social justice; drawing (M)")('1998092', 'Article on Houston Astros preparing for playoff series against San Diego Padres (M)')('1998092', 'Article on Chicago Cubs winning National League wild card playoff berth (M)')('1998092', 'Photo outside Metropolitan Opera at Lincoln Center (S)')('1998092', 'Harvey Araton Sports of The Times column discusses Chicago Cubs winning National League wild card playoff berth with victory over San Francisco Giants;
